content:
We currently show a special notice at the bottom of the three-dot menu for messages that were sent when you were not subscribed to the stream:

Screen-Shot-2022-10-03-at-12.56.26-PM.png

What are the reasons to do so? I'm not sure why this information would be important when viewing that menu, and I wonder whether we should drop it.

This previous topic about this just happened to be at the top of my #design unreads just now:

#design > "This message was sent before you were subscribed"
Heheh, amazing. I guess at the time nobody suggested a reason. ;)

This feature was added in ae4d248da300025493fb09c485d29308c6bade62, back in 2013. Commit messages were less good about explaining the motivation for changes back then :confused:.

Currently we surface whether a message was sent at such a time in a second way, via the "You (un)subscribed to this stream" type divider lines; that feature was added in 82da2bec107641998806b1855998c7e17f3546e4, aka about 6 days later also in 2013.

I think the motivation for this is likely somewhat subtle; but one thing it does is provides an explanation for "Why did I not find this message when searching my personal message history? It has the word X right there!", which is our default search behavior and the only thing we supported for search at the time.
(This is certainly not an elegant solution to that problem statement).
Yeah, that's probably neither a common question (especially now that you can search all public messages), nor a natural place to look for an answer to it.
A somewhat related topic: #general > (Un)subscribe UI event data
I filed Drop "(Message sent when you were not subscribed)" from three-dot message menu #23198.
